page.title: 19River Severn Navigation
page.content: One hundred and fifty years ago, Bridgnorth was the second busiest inland port in Europe, receiving barges that had travelled the length of the River Severn from Bristol with a wide variety of goods. Initially, the barges were pulled by 'bow-haulers' - noisy, uncouth men who terrorised the town with thir bad language and drunkeness when they lodged in Low Town overnight. Later, with the construction of a proper tow parh, horses were used to pull the barges. For half a century, the river has been silted-up and boats are able to travel on the Severn only as far as Bewdley. Now, the Severn Navigation Trust is conducting a 'Feasability Study' on making the river navigable between Bewdley and Ironbridge, with a series of locks and weirs at strategic points.
